You are correct that one of the motivations behind Reynald de Chatillon's decision to subject the Patriarch of Antioch, Aimery of Limoges, to the cruel treatment of being covered with honey and left exposed to insects on the roof of his castle was financial gain.

According to some accounts, Reynald demanded a large ransom from the Patriarch in exchange for his release, and when Aimery refused to pay, Reynald resorted to the extreme measure of subjecting him to the humiliating treatment of being covered with honey and exposed to insects. The incident was widely condemned by both Christians and Muslims at the time, and it contributed to Reynald's reputation as a cruel and brutal leader.

Reynald's actions towards the Patriarch of Antioch were just one example of his violent and aggressive behavior during the Crusades, and he was known for his repeated attacks against both Muslims and Christians who he perceived as his enemies. Ultimately, his actions led to his downfall when he was captured by Saladin's forces and executed in 1187.
